section_id: ## 5. Lemma 4: Minimal Antichain Selects Minimal Area Surface

hints.label: lem-minimality-via-scutoid
hints.title: Minimality Correspondence (Effective Area)
hints.content:
1573: :label: lem-minimality-via-scutoid
1574: 
1575: Let $A \subset \mathcal{X}$ be a spatial region. Among all surfaces $\Sigma$ homologous to $\partial A$ (i.e., separating $A$ from $\bar{A}$), the minimal antichain $\gamma_A$ corresponds to the surface $\partial A_{\min}$ with **minimal effective area**:
1576: 
1577: $$
1578: \partial A_{\min} = \arg\min_{\Sigma \sim \partial A} \mathcal{A}_{\text{eff}}(\Sigma) = \arg\min_{\Sigma \sim \partial A} \int_\Sigma \left[\rho_{\text{spatial}}(x)\right]^{(d-1)/d} \, d\Sigma(x)
1579: $$
1580: 
1581: **Statement**: As $N \to \infty$, episodes in $\gamma_A$ concentrate on $\partial A_{\min}$, the surface minimizing the effective area functional.

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-27
hints.content:
1585: 
1586: :::{prf:proof}
1587: **Proof strategy**: We combine results from both the probabilistic localization ({prf:ref}`lem-antichain-concentration`) and the graph-theoretic minimality ({prf:ref}`lem-antichain-maxflow-mincut`) to establish the correspondence.
1588: 
1589: **Step 1: Antichain cardinality via Lemma 3 (corrected)**
1590: 
1591: From Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-surface-riemann-sum` (corrected), the number of episodes in $\gamma_A$ (assuming they lie on surface $\Sigma$) is:
1592: 
1593: $$
1594: |\gamma_A| \approx C_d N^{(d-1)/d} \int_\Sigma \left[\rho_{\text{spatial}}(x)\right]^{(d-1)/d} \, d\Sigma(x)
1595: $$
1596: 
1597: **Step 2: Minimality of antichain**
1598: 
1599: By definition, $\gamma_A$ is the **minimal** separating antichain, meaning $|\gamma_A|$ is minimized among all separating antichains.
1600: 
1601: Different choices of separating surface $\Sigma$ (all homologous to $\partial A$) give different antichain cardinalities:
1602: 
1603: $$
1604: |\gamma_\Sigma| \approx C_d N^{(d-1)/d} \int_\Sigma \left[\rho_{\text{spatial}}(x)\right]^{(d-1)/d} \, d\Sigma(x)
1605: $$
1606: 
1607: **Step 3: Minimize the surface integral**
1608: 
1609: To minimize $|\gamma_A|$, we must minimize:
1610: 
1611: $$
1612: \int_\Sigma \left[\rho_{\text{spatial}}(x)\right]^{(d-1)/d} \, d\Sigma(x)
1613: $$
1614: 
1615: over all surfaces $\Sigma$ homologous to $\partial A$.
1616: 
1617: **Step 4: Define effective area functional**
1618: 
1619: The integral to be minimized (from Step 3) is:
1620: 
1621: $$
1622: \mathcal{A}_{\text{eff}}(\Sigma) := \int_\Sigma \left[\rho_{\text{spatial}}(x)\right]^{(d-1)/d} \, d\Sigma(x)
1623: $$
1624: 
1625: We call this the **effective area functional**. The minimal antichain corresponds to the surface that minimizes this weighted integral.
1626: 
1627: **Step 5: Analyze effective area for uniform fitness**
1628: 
1629: From {prf:ref}`rem-qsd-density-review`, when $U_{\text{eff}} = \text{const}$ (marginal-stability regime):
1630: 
1631: $$
1632: \rho_{\text{spatial}}(x) \propto \sqrt{\det g(x)}
1633: $$
1634: 
1635: Substituting into the effective area:
1636: 
1637: $$
1638: \mathcal{A}_{\text{eff}}(\Sigma) \propto \int_\Sigma \left[\sqrt{\det g(x)}\right]^{(d-1)/d} \, d\Sigma_g(x)
1639: $$
1640: 
1641: where $d\Sigma_g = \sqrt{\det g_\Sigma} \, du$ is the Riemannian surface measure.
1642: 
1643: **Key observation**: This is a **weighted Riemannian area**, not the standard geometric area $\int d\Sigma_g$. The weight factor $[\sqrt{\det g}]^{(d-1)/d}$ reflects the local Voronoi cell density.
1644: 
1645: **Relationship to standard minimal surfaces**: The surface minimizing $\mathcal{A}_{\text{eff}}$ may differ from the surface minimizing the standard area $\int d\Sigma_g$. However:
1646: - When $\det g(x)$ is constant (Euclidean flat space), the two coincide
1647: - When $\det g(x)$ varies slowly, the surfaces are close
1648: - The effective area is the **physically relevant quantity** for the discrete algorithm
1649: 
1650: **Step 6: General case - varying potential**
1651: 
1652: When $U_{\text{eff}}$ varies spatially:
1653: 
1654: $$
1655: \mathcal{A}_{\text{eff}}(\Sigma) = \int_\Sigma \left[\sqrt{\det g(x)} e^{-U_{\text{eff}}(x)/T}\right]^{(d-1)/d} \, d\Sigma_g(x)
1656: $$
1657: 
1658: The Boltzmann factor $e^{-U_{\text{eff}}/T}$ further modulates the effective area. Surfaces passing through high-fitness regions (low $U_{\text{eff}}$) have reduced effective area.
1659: 
1660: **Physical interpretation**: The swarm's natural dynamics favor surfaces that traverse favorable terrain, even if this increases the geometric area. This is analogous to light refracting through media with varying refractive index.
1661: 
1662: **Step 7: Synthesis of dual approaches**
1663: 
1664: This proof establishes the minimality correspondence using the Riemann sum convergence from {prf:ref}`lem-surface-riemann-sum`. The result is independently validated by two complementary arguments:
1665: 
1666: 1. **Probabilistic**: {prf:ref}`lem-antichain-concentration` shows antichains localize near separating surfaces with high probability (constant probability bounds from bounded martingale drift)
1667: 
1668: 2. **Graph-theoretic**: {prf:ref}`lem-antichain-maxflow-mincut` proves minimal antichains are exactly minimal cuts, which converge to minimal area surfaces via the Ford-Fulkerson theorem and variational calculus
1669: 
1670: The convergence of both approaches to the same result provides **robust verification** of the antichain-surface correspondence.

hints.label: rem-scutoid-energy-connection
hints.title: Connection to Scutoid Energy Functional
hints.content:
1676: :label: rem-scutoid-energy-connection
1677: 
1678: The minimality argument can also be derived from the **Hellinger-Kantorovich distance** energy functional from {prf:ref}`def-scutoid-energy` in {doc}`../14_scutoid_geometry_framework.md`:
1679: 
1680: $$
1681: E_{\text{scutoid}}(t \to t + \Delta t) = \text{HK}_{\alpha}(\mu_t, \mu_{t + \Delta t})^2
1682: $$
1683: 
1684: Minimal antichains correspond to minimal transport plans in the HK distance, which in turn correspond to geodesics in the Wasserstein space—precisely the minimal area surfaces in the emergent geometry.
